intro: Blepharoglossum grandiflorum, commonly known as the large-flowered forest fern, is a species native to the tropical regions of South America. It is a member of the Polypodiaceae family and is characterized by its intricate, delicate fronds that often exhibit a feathery appearance. The plant thrives in humid, shaded environments, typically found in the understory of tropical rainforests. Its spore-producing structures, called soruses, are clustered on the underside of its leaves, a typical feature of ferns. This plant plays an important ecological role in its habitat by contributing to soil stability and providing shelter for small organisms.
